timeline.bodyText: I suspect that rather than changing the format of the download reference, the warning could be resolved by adding a space to the original source code, between the link text and URL brackets. Like so, :download:ec2-create-instance.sh <https://...`.
timeline.author: mheppler
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -82,7 +82,9 @@ Download and Run the "Create Instance" Script
 
 Once you have done the configuration above, you are ready to try running the "ec2-create-instance.sh" script to spin up Dataverse in AWS.
 
-Download :download:`ec2-create-instance.sh<https://raw.githubusercontent.com/GlobalDataverseCommunityConsortium/dataverse-ansible/master/ec2/ec2-create-instance.sh>` and put it somewhere reasonable. For the purpose of these instructions we'll assume it's in the "Downloads" directory in your home directory.
+Download `ec2-create-instance.sh`_ and put it somewhere reasonable. For the purpose of these instructions we'll assume it's in the "Downloads" directory in your home directory.

replies.bodyText:
@mheppler nope. I just tried adding a space and I still got WARNING: download file not readable.
I'm pretty sure :download: only works on local files. Please see https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/restructuredtext/roles.html#referencing-downloadable-files
Now, there is an inline syntax that also works. It would look like this (you're right that a space is needed in this case):
Download `ec2-create-instance.sh <https://raw.githubusercontent.com/GlobalDataverseCommunityConsortium/dataverse-ansible/master/ec2/ec2-create-instance.sh>`_ and put it somewhere reasonable. For the purpose of these instructions we'll assume it's in the "Downloads" directory in your home directory.

I went with the non-inline syntax because the link is long. I find it more readable.
replies.author: pdurbin

replies.bodyText: Sorry, @pdurbin. Missed that it was not a local file. Changing it text link that opens an external page is totally kosher. 👍
